data.title: Susan L. Serbin's Talkin' 'Bout My Generation
data.meta_description: What's the fascination with going back in time to relive events?
data.text:
Deadlines:

Monday-Friday 8:30am-4:00pm, Call 610-915-2226

(Proofs will be provided for accuracy only, they will not be styled/formatted like the finished product)

Obituaries submitted on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays are accepted from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. by email only Obit@delcotimes.com

(No proofs will be furnished. Pricing will not be available until the next business day after 10:00am by calling Dianne at 610-915-2226)

Obituaries received after Deadline will not be published in the following edition of the paper.

Sending Procedure:

Email is the preferable method for receiving Obituaries (and the only method on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays), they can be sent to Obit@delcotimes.com (Feel free to call and confirm that we’ve received the email)

Formatting:

Obituaries will continue to visually look the same as they currently do, but you will no longer be restricted in what you can say (ex. As much Family can be listed as you’d like; Wording like “Went to rest with the Lord” is now permissible)

Other:

There is a cost for each obituary. Pricing and payments are only available Monday through Friday, 8:30 am to 4:00 pm. All weekend and holiday submissions will be provided a cost the next business day.

Exceptions:

All New accounts, Out of State Funeral Homes and Private Parties will require prepayment upon approval of the obituary. Weekend and Holiday staff are not authorized to set up a new account or process payments

Deadline for the above is before 4:00 PM Mon – Fri. only (Holiday schedules may vary).

Prepayment required submissions will be handled on the very first business day following the weekend and/or holiday schedule. A complete name, address and best contact phone number are required upon submittal of your obituary request to set up your account. A proof will then be emailed for review but placed on hold until payment is received.

Memory.

It’s one of the most frequent and common concerns of the ageing population. If I can’t remember a name, why was I able to pull a 40-year-old item from my brain files?

To better recall a particular experience, I said to myself (as always), I need to get into the Wayback Machine.

Did I lose you, or are you with me?

Flashback: Wayback came from the clever and extremely offbeat “Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle,” which ran from 1959 to 1964.

Featured were the main characters, plus others like Snidely Whiplash, and the pair of spies, Natasha Fatale and Boris Badenov.

Think Cold War.

Wayback was the invention of Dr. Peabody, a genius scientist, as well as a Beagle. Peabody created the machine to take “pet son” Sherman to a

time and place of historical importance, like the Charge of the Light Brigade.

Anything without electricity? No thanks.

By choosing time travel in popular culture as my topic, I quickly landed in familiar territory of being in over my head. Onto the research.

It wouldn’t be surprising to simply settle on “Back to the Future” as the benchmark, at least for our generation. But we’d be so wrong.

The first mention of time travel is said to have been a Hindu Epic around 400 B.C. There was also a reference of the theme in French literature during the 1600s.

Don’t confuse time travel fiction with prophetic works by seers, arguably the most famous of which is Nostradamous.

Those writers foretold, or guessed, the future, but didn’t really go there. Or did they?

Even through brief research, I found that time travel captured the imagination of writers across centuries. In some cases, the traveling device was magic, or at least mysterious.

In Charles Dickens’ “A Christmas Carol,” 1843, Ebenezer Scrooge traveled via ghosts.

H.G. Wells was among the first to bring mechanisms to life in 1895 with “The Time Machine.”

Literature is filled with time travelers, for good and evil. The young adult book, a Newberry Medal winner, “A Wrinkle in Time,” 1962, features a

cosmic sliver to enter the fifth dimension.

Look for wormholes, magic formulas — aka drugs — and strange talismans to make the trip.

Readers always bring their own interpretation and visualization to a story. In time travel, the who, what and where was theirs to create.

As of the 20th century, new movies and adaptations, then television and other entertainment media, showed the impossible to be possible.

The 1902 French film, “A Trip to the Moon,” is cited as the first of of its genre. Inspiration was a novel by Jules Verne, another science fiction genius.

It includes one of the most well-known moving picture images of a spaceship landing in the moon’s eye.

From then on, it was anything goes.

The perpetual Star-Trek series moved backwards, forwards and sideways around the galaxy.

Currently, the popular TV saga “Outlander,” based on a novel series, controls the calendar.

In this case, a World War II nurse “finds herself transported to 1743.” PTSD?

The website imdb.com lists 50 all-time best time travel films.

One of the loveliest was 1980’s “Somewhere in Time.” My favorite is Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” with its beautiful setting and inventive plot.

We appreciate the fantasy and are willing to suspend belief, but with some guidelines.

Backwards seems to dominate plots, perhaps because we knew and liked it. One is warned, however, we cannot change the past.

I close with a question: If Philadelphia International Airport became Philadelphia PAPTA (Pick-a-Place and Time) Airport, where would you go,

and what time period would you choose?

Will you stick to yesteryear, or is anyone willing to take a chance on the future?

Susan L. Serbin’s Talkin’ ‘Bout My Generation appears every other week.
